item.title: Oblivion Remastered: All Origins, Explained
item.description:
The Elder Scrolls 4: Oblivion Remastered takes all the things players love about the original game, puts a shiny new coat on them, buffs them up, adds a little luster, and recreates them all from scratch in an entirely new engine that tests the limits of your gaming machine.

The customization options in this iteration of Oblivion are quite in-depth, letting you pick different races, classes, and even origins. The origins of your character aren’t just for show, they do have an impact on your gameplay. If you're wondering exactly what effect your choice of origin will have on your character in Oblivion Remastered , read on to learn more.

What Are Origins in The Elder Scrolls 4: Oblivion Remastered?

Your character’s origin is essentially a roleplaying tool that you can use to flesh out the backstory of your character in the customization menu at the start of the game. This helps you immerse yourself in your in-game avatar and really dive into the game with gusto.

Each race has two origins, with each one having both gameplay and roleplay relevance. The origin you choose will give you a little bit of information about your past, but it will also change your stats to match that background. Choosing the right origin is quite important if you want to min-max your character.

All Origins in The Elder Scrolls 4: Oblivion Remastered

Since there are ten available races in the game, and each race has two origins, you have a total of twenty origins . You can only choose one of two origins, the ones related to your race, which simplifies the choice quite a bit. For each origin, you can see the stats it changes by pressing the relevant button (F in the case of the default controls on PC).

Here is every origin in The Elder Scrolls 4: Oblivion Remastered and the influence they have on your character's stats:

Race Origin Stat Difference
Argonian Arnesia 40 Intelligence, 45 Willpower, 50 Agility, 50 Speed
Thornmarsh 55 Intelligence, 45 Willpower, 40 Agility, 40 Speed
Breton Systres 40 Strength, 30 Speed
High Rock 30 Strength, 40 Speed
Dark Elf Vvardenfell 40 Endurance, 30 Personality
Mainland 30 Endurance, 40 Personality
High Elf Auridon 30 Speed, 40 Endurance
Summerset Isle 40 Speed, 30 Endurance
Imperial Nibenay 35 Willpower, 40 Speed
Colovia 45 Willpower, 30 Speed
Khajit Anequina 40 Strength, 30 Endurance
Pellitine 30 Strength, 40 Endurance
Nord Western 35 Willpower, 50 Endurance
Eastern 45 Willpower, 40 Endurance
Orc Stronghold 35 Intelligence, 55 Willpower, 30 Personality
Orsinium 45 Intelligence, 50 Willpower, 25 Personality
Redguard Dragontail Mountain 50 Strength, 30 Personality
Alik’r Desert 40 Strength, 40 Personality
Wood Elf Grahtwood 40 Endurance, 30 Personality
Reaper’s March 30 Endurance, 40 Personality
6 Images

item.title: Destiny 2: The Palindrome God Roll Guide (2025)
item.description:
The Palindrome is an iconic hand cannon in Destiny 2 that returned in a new form with Episode Heresy. The reprised hand cannon is now Arc instead of Void and has a couple of great new perks to try out in both PvE and PvP activities.

Below is a detailed overview of the definitive the Palindrome god rolls for both PvE and PvP in Destiny 2 . Alternative perks have also been provided in order to cater to different builds and playstyles.

Destiny 2: The Palindrome PvE God Roll

For PvE, the Palindrome has one definitive combination that allows the weapon to shine. It's the only hand cannon in Destiny 2 that can get Rolling Storm and is perfect if you're running a Titan with Storm's Keep or a Warlock with Ionic Sentry.

Here's the Palindrome PvE god roll:

Column 1

Column 2

Column 3

Column 4

Masterwork

Corkscrew Rifling

Tactical Mag

Explosive Payload

Rolling Storm

Range

The Palindrome is a rare case of a Nightfall weapon rolling Explosive Payload in the third column. Explosive Payload splits the damage into base and explosive, giving an approximate 15% damage increase without requiring you to do anything other than fire the weapon.

Explosive Payload in the third column allows you to lean into Bolt Charge with Rolling Storm in the fourth column. Rolling Storm grants stacks of Bolt Charge when killing targets (1 stack per kill) and offers increased effects if you're Amplified (2 stacks per kill).

There are other perks to go for in the fourth column, like Master of Arms and Magnificent Howl , if you're not a fan of Bolt Charge-focused builds. However, Rolling Storm is what makes the new The Palindrome stand out among the rest of the weapons.

Destiny 2: The Palindrome PvP God Roll

The PvP god roll is a bit more flexible and depends on your playstyle. While the Palindrome has classic perks, like Explosive Payload, there are other options available.

Here's the Palindrome PvP god roll:

Column 1

Column 2

Column 3

Column 4

Masterwork

Hammer-Forged Rifling

Accurized Rounds

Explosive Payload / To the Pain

Opening Shot

Range

Explosive Payload is a staple perk on hand cannons in PvP, thanks to the flinch it inflicts. But if you already have a good Rose with Explosive Payload, there's also To the Pain. To the Pain offers aim assist and handling as you take damage, making the weapon feel snappier. Regardless of the perk, you still need three precision hits to secure a kill in the Crucible, with the optimal time-to-kill being 0.87 seconds.

In the fourth column, the best perk is Opening Shot for a major aim assist and range boost for your first shot. It allows you to hit maximum range without any help from the weapon mods. A decent alternative to Opening Shot is Master of Arms . With one stack of Master of Arms, you need two precision shots and one body shot to secure a kill against Guardians with Tier 9 Resilience and below. However, this perk requires a kill to activate and lasts 7 seconds. It might be a fun choice in 6v6 playlists, but in Competitive or Trials of Osiris, you want a perk that consistently aids you in every duel.

Other notable perks in the fourth column include Snapshot Sights for faster ADS speed and Magnificent Howl for the ability to get empowered shots. Ultimately, it's all about what you need for the weapon to feel as comfortable as possible.

How To Get The Palindrome In Destiny 2

Like its previous version, the Palindrome is a Nightfall weapon in Destiny 2 . Nightfall weapons are on the weekly rotation, and when the Palindrome is the featured weekly weapon, you can farm Nightfalls for base versions or Grandmaster Nightfalls for Adept versions of the weapon.

Once you unlock the base version, you can focus it at Zavala for 5 Vanguard Engrams and 25,000 Glimmer, even if it's not the featured weapon.

item.title: Black Ops 6 Zombies: All Ray Gun Mark 2 Upgrades, Ranked
item.description:
The Ray Gun Mark 2 has 3 distinctive upgrade variants in Black Ops 6 ’s Shattered Veil map, and each of these variants offers players a unique way to shoot the undead, filled with different ammo types and fire-rates that will offer an exciting experience, but which of those experiences is the best for reaching high rounds?

With 3 Ray Gun Mark 2 upgrades in Black Ops 6 Zombies to look out for, it’s going to serve players well to know which one they should invest in unlocking, and why it’s going to be worth their time to grab these variants outside of the easter egg runs that they might seek.

3 Ray Gun Mark 2-R

The Long-Range Rot-Blight Firing Marksman Variant

  • How to Get the Ray Gun Mark 2-R

Upon upgrading the Ray Gun Mark 2 at the Garden Pond, players will now have a yellow variant to call their own. While it’s a cool weapon, the Ray Gun Mark 2-R quickly becomes more situational than a primary weapon, since it has a significantly lower rate of fire than the other two models. On top of the low fire rate, the Ray Gun Mark 2-R is also mainly used as a marksman rifle, meaning players are going to want to keep distance to fire accurate shots into their enemies – so this variant is still decent, but not to players who are fighting off hordes of undead without keeping the distance.

There are still advantages to the Ray Gun Mark 2-R, like how its range means it’s effective at taking out Parasites to stop them from creating Doppelghasts. This weapon also has great damage, and on the high rounds, that’s going to be great against Elder Disciples and the growing strength of zombies, paired only further by the toxic fumes that occasionally release upon killing a zombie to make those affected by it take damage over time.

2 Ray Gun Mark 2-P

A Shotgun Variant With a Chance of Invulnerability

  • How to Get the Ray Gun Mark 2-P

The Ray Gun Mark 2-P is the purple variant that can be upgraded via the Director’s Quarters. Upon upgrading to this variant, players are going to notice the difference in power compared to the other elements, so long as they are up close and personal. The Ray Gun Mark 2-P is a shotgun variant, meaning it benefits more from close-range engagements, which is going to be pretty easy to find when one considers that all zombies sprint towards players to try and hit them.

Having the Ray Gun Mark 2-P is extremely reliable for those always on the move, since it’s a variant that, when Pack-a-Punched, can shred through zombies that have gotten too close and are currently blocking off the escape route. With a rapid-fire mode with a shotgun spread, the Ray Gun Mark 2-P is great, even if it’s lacking in both magazine size and ammunition. However, when cornered, killing a zombie has a chance to drop a purple sigil that players can stand in to negate damage, allowing them to hold their ground a little longer.

1 Ray Gun Mark 2-W

The Fully Automatic Wraith Fire Model

  • How to Get the Ray Gun Mark 2-W

The undisputed king of the Ray Gun Mark 2 models is the Ray Gun Mark 2-W. This variant can be crafted from the Supply Depot, and it’s one that players certainly are not going to miss. With this blue variant in hand, players are going to throw away the three-round-burst model of the original, and instead have a fully-automatic Ray Gun Mark 2 that certainly doesn’t hold back. It has the magazine size and the rate of fire of a submachine gun, providing the fastest and most effective damage per second for rapid zombie kills.

With its fast fire rate and its hefty ammo size, players are going to be tearing through zombies with ease in the high rounds. There’s also the Wraith Fire ammo mod, meaning that occasional rapid kills with the Ray Gun Mark 2-W will spawn a blue flame on the ground that scorches and kills zombies that walk through it. With high damage, great ammo reserves, and a high rate of fire (even without Double Tap Root Beer), this variant truly becomes the best there is at killing zombies.

item.title: How To Join The Arena In Oblivion Remastered
item.description:
After a long wait, the remastered version of The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is finally here, and players can dive right back into its sprawling world. Once you exit the sewers, you’ll have access to a huge portion of the map, with the freedom to explore regions at your own pace or fast travel to far-off locations for easier access to quests and cities.

Whether you're sticking to the main questline or planning to join a guild, it's always smart to have some Gold saved up. And what better way to earn it than by taking on fierce opponents in the blood-soaked Arena? The Arena becomes available pretty early, offering both a steady income and a fun challenge. Here is how to join it in The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion Remastered .

How To Join The Arena In Oblivion Remastered

After completing the tutorial section of the game and exiting the sewers, open up the map and fast travel to Imperial City Arena . You can walk the whole way there, but it is recommended that you save time by fast traveling . You will spawn right outside the Arena, where you can find Hundolin . Talk to him, and he will tell you to speak with Owyn , the Blademaster . Turn left, and you will spot a door leading to the Arena Bloodworks .

Inside the Bloodworks, take the first left, and at the far end, you can find a grumpy Redguard. You can select the option to become a combatant, for which he will give you a Blue Raimen t that you must equip to fight in the Arena.

The timings for the Arena are from 9:00 AM to 9:00 PM , and you can simply talk to Owyn whenever you are ready for a match. Do keep in mind that upon winning, you should not try to loot the opponent's corpse, as that is forbidden .

Fighting In The Arena

After Owyn tells you to go up to the Arena, you can equip your magic spells and weapon and head through the door of the Arena . The first fight should be very easy and should not take you more than three minutes to complete. Once you are done, head back down the way you came and interact with the Basin of Renewal to restore Stamina, Magicka , and Health . Talking to Owyn again will reward you with 50 Gold , and you can start the next match right away. After every three matches, you rank up and get a Trophy/Achievement .

If you made your way to the Arena directly after exiting the Sewers, it is best to stop when you reach Bloodletter , as the fights will continue to become more challenging. You can continue when you level up and get more adept at the game's combat system.

item.title: How to Start the Shivering Isles DLC in Oblivion Remastered
item.description:
The Shivering Isles is the second main story DLC included from the original release that is now included in Oblivion Remastered . This legendary story expansion has long been considered one of the greatest ever made, and its inclusion here will only serve to solidify its position. The Shivering Isles is generally considered to be the late-game DLC that players should undertake once they have completed the main story, though this is not required. Whether you are a new player visiting the isles for the first time, or a longtime fan looking for a refresher, this guide will show you how to start The Shivering Isles DLC in Oblivion Remastered .

How to Start The Shivering Isles DLC in Oblivion Remastered

Complete the Tutorial:

While many players recommend waiting until you've completed the main story to begin The Shivering Isles DLC , it seems that the only actual requirement for starting this story expansion in Oblivion Remastered is completing the game's opening tutorial. However, just because you can start it that early, doesn't mean you should.

While you absolutely can – and likely should – start and complete the Knights of the Nine DLC before completing the main quest, it is worth waiting until your character is well-developed before having your fateful meeting with Haskill at the Strange Door.

Visit the Strange Door:

In the original version of Oblivion , players had to let 24 in-game hours pass after completing the tutorial before they could access the Strange Door , and the " A Door in Niben Bay " quest. We assumed that would carry over, and used the time-passing mechanic in the game to do so.

Once you've completed the opening tutorial, you'll need to head to the Strange Door island in Niben Bay, which is located off the east coast of The Heartlands . The nearest town is Bravil, which is the best fast-travel destination .

After exiting the gates of Bravil into the Heartlands, you can easily swim to the island in the center of the bay. You can see the head-shaped rock that marks the Strange Door. As you approach the door, the " A Door in Niben Bay " quest will automatically start.

Speak to the NPCs that are standing in front of the portal at the Strange Door. Shortly after doing so, an enemy should emerge and begin attacking Gaius Prentus. Speak to him again after the attack to move the quest forward.

Enter the Portal at the Strange Door:

Once you've exhausted all dialogue, enter the portal at the Strange Door. Inside, you'll meet a strange NPC named Haskill. He'll give you a rundown of what the Shivering Isles DLC will entail.

After Haskill gives you his pitch, he will tell you to think it over and return to him when you are ready. You can either speak to him right away, or come back later when you are better prepared. If and when you agree to be Sheogorath 's mortal champion, there will be an amazing visual sequence as the surrounding structure disappears.

This will end "A Door in Niben Bay" and begin the next quest in The Shivering Isles, beginning the DLC in earnest.
